title: What is the equation of the circle whose center is (5, 6) and radius is 3? - Quora
tags: Middle and High School Math Homework Question

response.answer_text: I am giving a brief information for this question. A Circle is defined by this equation :  Where,  is the ordered pair for the centre of the given circle. By graphing your given circle, we get:  By analysing, we can conclude that  is  and radius . So the equation becomes:  This was the questioned equation…

When I went to school it was X minus 5 squared plus Y minus 6 squared equals 9. Quite obvious really if you know that a circle of radius 3 centred on the origin is x^2 + y^2 = 9. To shift the circle to (5,6) you change X to x-5 and y to y-6. It requires some practice and serious thought before you understand what you're really doing, but it's worth it. A degree in civil engineering earns you about 70,000 dollars annually these days.

We know the equation of the circle having centre (h,k) and radius r is (x - h)^2 +(y- k )^2 = r^2 . Here h = 5, k=6 & r =3 , so the equation of the circle is ( x - 5)^2 + (y - 6 )^2 = 3^2 or, x^2 -10x + 25 + y^2 - 12y + 36 - 9=0 i.e., x^2 +y^2 -10x - 12y +52 = 0
(x-a)^2+(y-b)^2=(r)^2 Where (a,b) is the centre of the circle and r is the radius. So, equation of circle is : (x-5)^2+(y-6)^2=9

[math](x-h)^2+(y-k)^2=r^2[/math] where [math](h,k)[/math] is the center of the circle, and [math]r[/math] is the radius. In your question: center of circle at [math](5,6)[/math]and radius of 3 units: [math]h=5,k=6,r=3[/math] [math](x-5)^2+(y-6)^2=3^2[/math] which simplifies to: [math](x-5)^2+(y-6)^2=9[/math]

(X-5)^2+(Y-6)^2=3^2=9 Circle with given center and radius is of the form (x-h)^2+(y-k)^2=r^2 Where the ordered pair (h,k) is the center.
